section_1_sacred_text.original_script: Τῇ δὲ ἐπαύριον ὁδοιπορούντων ἐκείνων καὶ τῇ πόλει ἐγγιζόντων ἀνέβη Πέτρος ἐπὶ τὸ δῶμα προσεύξασθαι περὶ ὥραν ἕκτην.
section_1_sacred_text.faithful_direct_translation: On the next day, while those ones were journeying and drawing near to the city, Peter went up upon the rooftop to pray, around the sixth hour.
section_1_sacred_text.standalone_english_translation: About noon the next day, as they were on their journey and approaching the city, Peter went up on the roof to pray.
section_1_sacred_text.amplified_narrative_translation: Meanwhile, on the following day, as Cornelius's men were continuing their journey and were now drawing near to the city of Joppa, Peter ascended to the flat rooftop of the house, intending to pray at the pivotal (significant moment or turning point) time of about the sixth hour, which is high noon.

interlinear_analysis.contextual_meaning: Functions as a dative of time, translated 'On the...' referring to the next day.
A transitional conjunction, marking a shift in scene from Cornelius's men to Peter, best translated as 'Now' or 'Meanwhile'.
Specifies the time frame as the day following the departure of the messengers from Caesarea (Acts 10:7-8).

interlinear_analysis.contextual_meaning: Part of a genitive absolute clause, describing the ongoing action of Cornelius's men traveling.
Refers back to the men sent by Cornelius, serving as the subject of the genitive absolute clause: 'while those men were journeying...'
Connects the two participial phrases describing the men's progress: 'journeying AND drawing near'.
The article for 'city', in the dative case because the verb 'drawing near' takes a dative object.
Refers to Joppa, where Peter was staying.

interlinear_analysis.parsing_expanded: Verb, Participle, Present, Active, Genitive, Masculine, Plural
interlinear_analysis.contextual_meaning: The second participle in the genitive absolute, indicating the messengers' proximity to their destination.

interlinear_analysis.contextual_meaning: The main verb of the sentence, describing Peter's specific action. The aorist tense indicates a completed action.
The subject of the main verb 'anebē' (he went up).
Indicates direction and destination: 'onto the rooftop'.
The flat roof of a house, a common place in the ancient Near East for privacy, coolness, and prayer.
An infinitive of purpose, explaining why Peter went up to the roof: 'for the purpose of praying'.
Refers to a specific point in time.
Specifies the hour. By Jewish and Roman reckoning, this was noon, the middle of the day.

linguistic_mechanics_and_names.theological_significance: The name Peter, given by Jesus, means 'rock' (from Greek petra). His actions in this chapter are foundational for the Gentile mission, as he becomes the 'rock' or key figure through whom God officially opens the door of faith to non-Jews, fulfilling his role given in Matthew 16:18-19. The etymology (the study of the origin of words) of his name is deeply tied to his apostolic function.

This verb is a compound of 'pros' (toward) and 'euchomai' (to wish, vow). It signifies a deliberate act of turning one's focus toward God. Peter's action is not accidental; he seeks a specific time and place for communion with God. It is in this posture of intentional prayer that he receives divine revelation, a common pattern throughout Scripture (e.g., Daniel, Paul).

The rooftop was a place of elevation, separation, and openness to the heavens. Going 'up' to the roof symbolizes seeking a higher perspective, away from earthly distractions, to meet with God. It is a physical act reflecting a spiritual desire for communion and revelation, making it an ideal setting for the vision that follows.

This refers to noon, a time of full light and the day's turning point. It is a biblically significant time. At the sixth hour, darkness covered the land during Christ's crucifixion (Luke 23:44), marking the ultimate turning point in salvation history. Here, at the sixth hour, a new light of revelation comes to Peter that will turn the course of the early church toward the Gentiles.

section_2_exegetical_synthesis.literary_devices: The primary literary device is the use of a genitive absolute (a grammatical construction in Greek) with two participles: 'while those men were journeying (ὁδοιπορούντων, hodoiporountōn)... and drawing near (ἐγγιζόντων, engizontōn)'. Luke uses this to create narrative suspense and dramatic irony. The reader knows the Gentile messengers are approaching, but Peter, isolated on the rooftop in prayer, is completely unaware. This technique masterfully interweaves two separate plotlines, highlighting God's sovereign timing in bringing them to a divine intersection.
section_2_exegetical_synthesis.aggregate_analogia_scriptura: This verse resonates with several scriptural themes. The practice of fixed-hour prayer is seen in Daniel 6:10 (three times a day) and Psalm 55:17 ('evening, morning and at noon'). Peter's action aligns with this pious (devoutly religious) Jewish custom. The rooftop as a place of revelation connects to Samuel anointing Saul (1 Samuel 9:25-26). Most importantly, Peter's experience of receiving a world-changing vision while in prayer parallels Daniel's vision (Daniel 9:20-21) and Ananias's vision regarding Saul (Acts 9:10-12). The subsequent inclusion of the Gentiles is the direct fulfillment of OT prophecies like Isaiah 49:6, where God's salvation reaches 'to the ends of the earth'. Peter, prepared by prayer, becomes the human agent for this prophetic fulfillment.
literal_primary_filter: The day after Cornelius dispatched his men, they were traveling.
As they neared the city of Joppa, their destination.
An apostle named Peter went up onto the flat roof of the house where he was staying.
His stated purpose for going to the roof was to pray.
The time of this event was approximately noon.

prophetic_typology_and_intertextuality.type_shadow: The physical separation of Jew and Gentile, codified in the Mosaic Law's clean/unclean distinctions (Leviticus 11), serves as a 'type' or shadow. Peter's current understanding is still bound by this separation.
prophetic_typology_and_intertextuality.antitype_fulfillment: The 'antitype' (the reality to which the type points) is the spiritual unity of all people in Christ. The vision Peter is about to receive (Acts 10:10-16) will serve as the divine declaration that what God has cleansed (through the blood of Christ) is no longer to be considered 'unclean'. Christ is the fulfillment who breaks down the 'dividing wall of hostility' (Ephesians 2:14).
prophetic_typology_and_intertextuality.progression_notes: This event is a pivotal moment in redemptive history. It marks the programmatic shift from a primarily Jewish-centric ministry to the intentional, church-sanctioned mission to the Gentiles. It is the practical outworking of the 'and to the end of the earth' clause of the Great Commission (Acts 1:8).

section_2_exegetical_synthesis.numerical_and_gematria_significance: The 'sixth hour' (noon) is the most significant number here. It is a time of climax and transition. In John's Gospel, Jesus meets the Samaritan woman (a non-Jew) at Jacob's well 'about the sixth hour' (John 4:6), initiating a move beyond Jewish boundaries. At the 'sixth hour,' Jesus is presented by Pilate, 'Behold your King!' (John 19:14), and at the 'sixth hour,' darkness falls over the cross (Luke 23:44). Peter's vision at this same hour places this new revelation—the inclusion of the Gentiles—on par with these other climactic, salvation-historical moments. It is a 'high noon' moment for the church's mission.

historical_context_and_chronology.dates: This event occurs approximately 8-10 years after Christ's ascension, around AD 38-40. This places it during the reign of the Roman Emperor Caligula (AD 37-41).
historical_context_and_chronology.context: First-century Judean houses commonly featured flat roofs made of packed earth and clay over wooden beams. These rooftops served as extra living space, especially in the cool of the evening, and were ideal for private activities like prayer. The 'sixth hour' was noon, a standard time for prayer for devout Jews, corresponding to the time of the second daily temple sacrifice. Peter's adherence to this schedule shows he is still a devout, law-observant Jew just before receiving a vision that will radically alter his understanding of that Law.

section_2_exegetical_synthesis.socio_political_matrix: The setting is Joppa (modern Jaffa), a major port city with a mixed population but a strong Jewish identity. Peter is staying with 'Simon, a tanner' (Acts 9:43), a trade considered ceremonially unclean because it involved contact with dead animals. This detail subtly prefigures the theme of the chapter: God is breaking down barriers of 'uncleanness'. The approaching men are emissaries of a Roman centurion, a symbol of the occupying military power. The meeting about to occur between a Jewish apostle and the servants of a Roman officer is socially and religiously radical, challenging deep-seated cultural divisions.

geospatial_and_physical_geography.modern_location: Joppa (ancient Yoppa, modern Jaffa), now part of the municipality of Tel Aviv-Yafo, Israel.
geospatial_and_physical_geography.terrain_climate_characteristics: Joppa is a natural harbor on the Mediterranean coast. The terrain is a low coastal plain. The climate is Mediterranean, characterized by hot, dry summers and mild, wet winters. A rooftop at noon in this climate would have been hot and exposed to the full sun, suggesting Peter sought solitude even at the cost of comfort.

section_2_exegetical_synthesis.archaeological_confirmation: Excavations in Jaffa have uncovered remains from the Hellenistic and Roman periods, confirming its existence as a significant port city as described in the Bible and by historians like Josephus. While the specific house of Simon the Tanner cannot be identified, the architectural style of Roman-era courtyard houses with external staircases leading to flat roofs is well-attested throughout the region, providing a solid archaeological backdrop for the narrative's setting.

geographic_calculations.uncertainty_notes: The journey would have followed the relatively flat and well-established Roman coastal road, the Via Maris. The text implies a two-day journey; they left on one day (10:8), were traveling 'on the next day' (10:9), and arrived 'on the following day' (10:24). This fits the calculated distance for travel on foot perfectly.

section_3_life_application: Just as Peter set aside a specific time and place for prayer, we should cultivate intentional rhythms of communion with God. Our routines are not interruptions to God's work; they are the very places He often chooses to give us new direction. This verse challenges us to be people of prayer, prepared for God to sovereignly arrange 'divine intersections' in our lives. We must be willing to ascend to our own 'rooftop'—a place of spiritual focus—so we can hear God's call to move beyond our cultural comfort zones and personal prejudices to embrace the full scope of His redemptive mission.
